pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:0.2: The monks’ rules and their analysis
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:0.3: The chapter on offenses entailing confession
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:1.1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:1.1.2: At that time the Master gave many talks about the Monastic Law, spoke in praise of the Monastic Law and of learning the Monastic Law, and he repeatedly praised Venerable Upāli.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:1.1.3: When the monks heard this, they thought,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:1.1.5: “Well then, let’s learn the Monastic Law from Venerable Upāli.” And many monks, both senior and junior, as well as those of middle standing, learned the Monastic Law from Upāli.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:1.1.6: The monks from the group of six thought,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:1.1.7: “If these monks become well-versed in the Monastic Law,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:1.1.8: they’ll push us around and pull us about as they like, wherever they like, to whatever extent they like.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:1.1.9: So let’s disparage the Monastic Law.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:1.1.10: And they approached the other monks and said,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:1.1.11: “What’s the point of reciting these minor and insignificant training rules, when they just lead to anxiety, oppression, and annoyance?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:1.1.12: The monks of few desires complained and criticized them,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:1.1.13: “How can the monks from the group of six disparage the Monastic Law?” …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:1.1.14: “Is it true, monks, that you do this?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:1.1.17: Foolish men, how can you disparage the Monastic Law?
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:1.1.18: This will not give rise to confidence in those without it …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:1.1.19: And, monks, this training rule should be recited thus:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:1.1.20: ‘When the Monastic Code is being recited, if a monk says, “What’s the point of reciting these minor and insignificant training rules, when they just lead to anxiety, oppression, and annoyance?” then in disparaging the training rules, he commits an offense entailing confession.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:2.1.5: … The monk who has been given the full ordination by a complete Order through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements that is irreversible and fit to stand—this sort of monk is meant in this case.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:2.1.6: When the Monastic Code is being recited:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:2.1.7: when reciting it, when getting it recited, or when practicing it.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:2.1.9: “What’s the point of reciting these minor and insignificant training rules, when they just lead to anxiety, oppression, and annoyance?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:2.1.10: If he disparages the Monastic Law to one who is fully ordained, saying, “Those who learn this will be anxious/will feel oppressed/will be annoyed, but those who don’t learn this will not be anxious/will not feel oppressed/will not be annoyed. It’s better left unrecited/it’s better left unlearned/it’s better left unstudied/it’s better left unmastered. Let the Monastic Law disappear, or let these monks remain ignorant,” then he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:2.2.1: If he disparages the Monastic Law to one who is fully ordained, and he perceives them as fully ordained, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:2.2.2: If he disparages the Monastic Law to one who is fully ordained, but he is unsure if they are, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:2.2.3: If he disparages the Monastic Law to one who is fully ordained, but he does not perceive them as fully ordained, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:2.2.4: If he disparages some other rule, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:2.2.5: If he disparages the Monastic Law or some other rule to one who is not fully ordained, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:2.2.6: If it is to one who is not fully ordained, but he perceives them as fully ordained, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:2.2.7: If it is to one who is not fully ordained, but he is unsure of it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:2.2.8: If it is to one who is not fully ordained, and he does not perceive them as fully ordained, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:2.3.2: if, not desiring to disparage, he says, “Listen, learn discourses/verses/philosophy, and later you can learn the Monastic Law;”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:2.3.4: if he is the first offender.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:2.3.5: The second rule, the training rule on annoyance, is finished.
